content: The Act is titled the "Energy Workforce for the 21st Century Act of 2015" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Energy Workforce for the 21st Century Act of 2015" defines key terms such as community college, Department of Energy, elementary school, institution of higher education, and minority-serving institution. The "Energy Workforce for the 21st Century Act of 2015" defines key terms such as historically Black colleges or universities, Predominantly Black Institutions, Hispanic-serving institutions, Tribal Colleges or Universities, National Laboratory, and program. The "Energy Workforce for the 21st Century Act of 2015" defines key terms such as secondary school, Secretary, and STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics). The "Energy Workforce for the 21st Century Act of 2015" defines key terms related to energy and manufacturing workforce development. The "Energy Workforce for the 21st Century Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary to establish a program to enhance education and training for energy and manufacturing jobs, focusing on increasing skilled workers in these fields. This includes encouraging underrepresented groups to enter STEM fields, equipping students with necessary skills, mentorships, and technical expertise, and providing opportunities for gaining essential skills for employment. The Secretary is mandated to establish a program to enhance education and training for energy and manufacturing jobs, prioritizing underrepresented groups. Direct assistance will be provided to schools, colleges, and organizations for skills development and partnerships. The Secretary will distribute direct assistance to workforce development organizations, labor organizations, apprenticeship programs, tribal colleges, and minority-serving institutions based on needs in energy and manufacturing industries. A clearinghouse will be established to maintain information on training programs and provide guidance to educational institutions. The Secretary will collaborate with various educational institutions, workforce training organizations, and industry organizations to develop energy- and manufacturing-related training programs. This collaboration includes secondary schools, community colleges, minority-serving institutions, tribal colleges, labor organizations, National Laboratories, and State energy offices. The Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act aims to promote collaboration among entities providing job training programs in energy- and manufacturing-related fields, including labor organizations, industries, schools, and workforce development organizations. The Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act promotes collaboration among entities for job training programs in energy and manufacturing fields. This includes schools, workforce development programs, and industry partnerships to understand workforce needs. The Secretary will publish an annual report on job creation in these industries. The Secretary, in collaboration with other government agencies and industry, will develop guidelines for educational institutions to prepare graduates for energy- and manufacturing-related jobs at all levels of education. The Secretary will develop guidelines for educational institutions to prepare graduates for energy- and manufacturing-related jobs, including input from various industries. The guidelines will focus on teaching energy and manufacturing efficiency, conservation initiatives, and promoting STEM education for job opportunities in these fields nationally. Outreach to Minority-Serving Institutions: The Secretary will prioritize increasing outreach to minority-serving institutions, provide resources to train skilled minorities and women for energy and manufacturing sectors, promote industry internships for minority students, and collaborate with National Laboratories to enhance opportunities for underrepresented groups. The Secretary will focus on outreach to displaced and unemployed energy and manufacturing workers, providing resources for training and encouraging industries to offer internships and work-study programs. The Secretary will consult with energy and manufacturing industries to develop guidelines for workforce skills in sectors like energy efficiency and pipeline construction.
